Even without a Great Pumpkin, life's still great. You gotta seize it with two hands and live it large... Which is why I'm not happy about maybe spending my last hours on this ugly planet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowman's at a table, studying a computer. Via radio -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: I'm not getting anywhere, Houston. The only hope's to repair MEV, but everything they need was at Hab, and Hab's gone. As she talks, she closes the data file she's in and returns to something resembling a "home page." (She's accessing the mission's voluminous and detailed briefing materials, as was done earlier with the HHCs.)

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Put your skulls together down there, boys. And do it quick... Mars-1 out.

dialogues.speaker: ON COMPUTER
dialogues.text: Bowman's scanning a table of contents on the home page. Moves the cursor to a "History of Mars Exploration" section. Stops at the first category: "Early Russian Missions." Pauses. Clicks on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medium resolution. MOVING. Looking for something... then stopping. Apparently on nothing... and then the CAMERA ZOOMS IN... and suddenly we're looking at a strange object squatting on metal legs in the red Martian dust... ZOOMS IN more... and now we see the cyrillic lettering on top. REVEAL...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowman's looking at the cyrillic writing on Mars-1's high-res viewer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher, Burchenal, and Pettengill wait in silence. After a few moments, the RADIO CRACKLES --

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Gallagher.

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL
dialogues.text: Let's hope it's something good.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: (into radio) Go.  93 94 RED PLANET - Rev. 11/29/99 58.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: You guys sitting down...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've heard the plan. It leaves a lot to be desired.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: We walk 100 kilometers to a 30- year-old Russian rock probe that failed to launch and try to jump- start it... Gee, you couldn't make it tough? INTERCUT Bowman and Gallagher. She's watching them on the viewer.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: The probe's called Cosmos. Houston found the designer. Name's Borokovski. Owns a deli in Brooklyn. He thinks the launch sequence can be reprogrammed on site.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: If not, maybe he can send up a couple salami-on-ryes.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Here's the big thing... You've got just nineteen hours to get there and get it off the ground. So you better get moving. As they exchange looks and stand --

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I take back what I said about not making it tough.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: I gotta ditch the 'B' tank and burn more fuel from 'A' just to hold orbit that long... I can't burn more after that or Mars-1 won't have enough fuel to get home.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: (into radio) Which way we going? I needa heading. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 95 RED PLANET - Rev. 11/29/99 59.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bowman uses the viewer to figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Your eleven. More. (as he turns) There.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: (to the others) Let's go. As they head off --

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: I have work to do here. Then I'1l be in comm blackout on the dark side. Call you when I come back around.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Roger... And thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Wish it could be more.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Hey, it's something... and it's nice just knowing you're still up there.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: «+. I don't mind dying, but I hate the idea of being alone. So you guys stay in high gear. I want to see friendly faces around here again. OFF which...

dialogues.speaker: ON GALLAGHER'S FRIENDLY FACE
dialogues.text: Smiling big.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Hi. REVEAL Bowman in the doorway looking in.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Hi. She tries to look past him. He moves to block her view. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 95 RED PLANET - Rev. 11/10/99 60.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Fine... As soon as someone tells me why there's an indicator on the flight deck saying the temperature in here's above normal. About ten degrees.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: .-. Fahrenheit or centigrade? Then she blows past him. Finds Burchenal tending a huge contraption of glass tubing, Bunsen burners and filtration tanks.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: He's teaching me. About biology. I've developed an interest in --

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Fermentation? (then) A few billion taxpayer dollars in this mission, and you're using the lab equipment for a still.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: We're sterilizing it.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Nice try. (then) What's the fermentation base?

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Freeze-dried taters.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: How would you propose I explain to Houston that two of my crew went blind on moonshine vodka?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Carefully? Bowman eyes them both darkly a long moment. Then --

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: So, what, this establishment doesn't serve women? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 95 96 RED PLANET - Rev. 11/29/99 61.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They're off the hook. Burchenal pours her a cup. She looks at it. Tosses it back. Woooof.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: You making hootch or jet gas? (then) How much you got so far?

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: About three liters.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: You're done. Dismantle this thing. Offer equal rations to Pettengill and Chantilas. (then) Lieutenant Santen doesn't drink or approve of those who do... Since he's on duty on the flight deck, what he doesn't know won't hurt him. How much're you cutting this?

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: It's about seventy-five percent alcohol... Can't believe you took it in one shot standing up.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: I learned to drink in the Navy, boys. OFF which, as Bowman pours herself another snootful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chantilas and Pettengill have joined Gallagher, Bowman and Burchenal. There's only a little vodka left. They're all looped.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: +. I can figure out what went wrong on Mars. I can probably fix it. And then mankind'1l build burger franchises and breed like guppies and destroy the planet, too. And then it's really good-bye, ‘cause there aren't any more friendly ones... We're buying a couple hundred years, tops.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Maybe we've learned a lesson from what happened on Earth. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RED PLANET - Rev. 11/29/99 62.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: (beat; to Chantilas) There were frogs around when you were a kid, right?

dialogues.speaker: CHANTILAS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: And then we killed 'em. Every last one... Since frogs breathe through their skin and react to toxins in the environment faster, that should've been a warning, don't you think? Canary in the coal mine kind of thing?

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: What's your point?

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Man's a party animal. If we're doing okay, nothing else matters. That's not gonna change.

dialogues.speaker: CHANTILAS
dialogues.text: Unless there are larger forces than biology at work.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. We gonna talk God now? ‘Cause I'll need another pop.

dialogues.speaker: CHANTILAS
dialogues.text: Not God. Faith.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Faith?... Had a girl friend named Faith. She cheated on me... with a girl named Chastity. Burchenal's fun when he's drunk.

dialogues.speaker: CHANTILAS
dialogues.text: You're riding 309 million kilometers into outer space and back in a rocket ship nobody ever had time to test properly. You don't do that without a little faith.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Can't argue with that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHANTILAS
dialogues.text: Works that way with life, too. Sooner or later, we surrender to things beyond our control. To do that and still keep moving forward requires we believe ina right outcome.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Gotta have hope, right?

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Hope's just another way of postponing disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: CHANTILAS
dialogues.text: And I believe it's the only way we can realize the very best in us... Which, by the way, also happens to be a pretty good definition for God.

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL
dialogues.text: (to Chantilas) If you're American, how come you sound British? He's totally ignored. Continuing --

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Listen, forget hypotheticals for a moment, alright?... I say to hell with humanity,. I say we get to Mars, and we take it over for ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Radio back? Say it sucks and don't bother coming?

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Whatever keeps out the riff-raff .-. Chantilas can handle the religion thing. Gallagher can keep the space john working. Pettengill's... (looks at him) «+. passed out... And I'll handle pretty much everything else. Y'know -- King.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: And what about me? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He gives her a drunken smile.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Propagation of the species. Chantilas rolls his eyes, then stands, ending this line of discourse.

dialogues.speaker: CHANTILAS
dialogues.text: And with that, I suggest we go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: (off Bowman's look) Think I'll take the suggestion. He stands, and saying their "good nights," they head out, taking Pettengill with them. When they're gone --

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Heavy stuff. Smart people.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: How about you, Gallagher? Never heard you express an opinion.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Okay. I think you should wear a bra. That shuts her up for a few moments. Then --

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Bras are designed to support your breasts on Earth, where there's real gravity. Why would I need one in space?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: ‘Cause it's very distracting. (then) Not as distracting as seeing you step out of the shower, but...

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: I make sure to lock the door now.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I know. Tried walking in on you by accident a dozen times since then. He looks serious. Beat. He smiles. It's a joke. A smile breaks on Bowman's face. Then -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 96 97 RED PLANET - Rev. 11/29/99 65.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Y'know, you're not who I thought you were at first.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: That an insult or a compliment?

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: An observation. Beat. They're very close. And very drunk. It's when he should kiss her. But he doesn't. The moment passes. They both know it was there and now it's gone. Drift apart. Feel stupid... END OF FLASHBACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher, Pettengill and Burchenal move across the landscape strung out in a single line. Miles from where they started. Everyone's breathing hard. Pettengill and Gallagher doing better than Burchenal, who's dragging behind. Right now, Gallagher's in front. OVER the COMM-LINKS --

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Sure we're heading the right way?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Pretty sure.

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL
dialogues.text: --. We all make mistakes now and then.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Everyone but the king.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: (between breaths) No, no, there was one time.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: One time. Whoa.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Cloning potatoes... Spent two years trying to make a better spud and two more trying to stop it. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Almost wiped out Idaho. (beat, then) Of course, it turned out to be my assistant's fault. Pettengill stops, suddenly alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: (stops) What? Pettengill points off into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL
dialogues.text: Over there. Like the ground's moving.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I don't see anything.

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL
dialogues.text: .»-. It's gone now. But I definitely saw something. Gallagher looks at him a moment, wondering if Pettengill's hallucinating... When his eyes go to Burchenal for the first time. He sees that Burchenal's fallen way behind... And that AMEE's drone is hovering directly over his head.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: (tense, concerned) Burchenal, you're too far back!

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Drone zeroing in on me?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Affirmative. As Burchenal picks up the pace, OVER the RADIO we hear --

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Gallagher?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: (into radio; still watching Burchenal) Hey... I need a heading check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can see them on the high-res viewer.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: You're right on target. (beat; grave) We need to talk. Gallagher TURNS OFF his COMM-LINK.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I'm off the comm-link. What's up? Bowman's never hesitated in the execution of her command responsibilities. She does now. What she's about to say is hard even for her.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Bowman? And then --

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: The only place to ride Cosmos is inside the rock sample container.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Sounds comfy.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: It's very small... Houston and Borokovksi have been going over the schematics. They've done all they could to figure out how to cram three people in. (then) They couldn't. (then) Only two people fit, Gallagher. Two people barely. The news storms Gallagher's head. He just stands there. Trying to absorb it.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: «+. someone has to stay behind...

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: (beat) I'm sorry. Pettengill and Burchenal are getting near. To Bowman -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. I'11 talk to you later. He lowers the radio. As Burchenal walks up --

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: How we doing? Gallagher hesitates, weighs telling him. Then answers.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Fine... Good... OFF Gallagher, falling in with him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burchenal's slowing again, the pain holding him back. He glances up at the sound of AMEE's DRONE over his head. Tries to move faster. Does for a few moments. Then can't keep it up. Stops.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Shit...

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: (turns; calls back) Keep moving!

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: --. I'm hurt, I'm tired, I'm thirsty... I can't do this. He falls on the ground. Gallagher sees and stops.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Get up!

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Screw it. I'm through. The drone's circling like a buzzard. Gallagher looks at him. He and Pettengill could leave now, and there'd be no decision about who's going on Cosmos and who's staying behind. Beat. Beat. Then Gallagher starts hustling back to Burchenal. Passes Pettengill, who just watches him go by. Gallagher reaches Burchenal. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: You want to know what AMEE's going to do to you?

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: I don't give a damn.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Get your ass up! Gallagher hoists him up. It hurts, but Burchenal stands.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: -+. This air's too damn thin. I can barely breathe... Gallagher puts a hand in Burchenal's back. Starts pushing him.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: C'mon. Left foot, right foot, hop like a bunny -- I don't care. Let's go. Burchenal groans, but he's doing what Gallagher says. He has no choice. It's either that or fall on his face... They plod ahead like that for awhile. When Gallagher starts singing --

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: ‘Better stop, look around. Here it comes, here it comes, here it comes. Here comes your nineteenth nervous breakdown -- '

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: What the hell're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: My grandfather always sang this Rolling Stones song. That's the only part I remember. (sings) ‘Better stop, look around. Here it comes -- ' Burchenal groans.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: -- here it comes, here it comes. Here comes your nineteenth nervous breakdown...' (beat) C'mon. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RED PLANET - Rev. 11/10/99 70.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: ‘Better stop -- '

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowman's got them in the viewfinder once more. Making measurements. Scanning Mars... When something catches her eye. Something obscuring the Martian surface. Something large.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher's still singing. Clearly, he's worn down Burchenal, because Burchenal's into it now too. And Pettengill's joined in.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: ‘Here comes your nineteenth nervous breakdown -- '

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Gallagher. He keys the mike.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: ‘Better stop -- '

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: ‘Look around -- '

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: ‘Here it comes -- '

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Gallagher.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: ‘Here it comes --

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL
dialogues.text: ‘Here it comes --'

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: ‘Here comes your nineteenth --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowman's agitated. Wants ‘em to shut up.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Cut it! They hear it. The next line falling apart in their mouths --

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: -- nervous breakdown...

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: (then) There's an icestorm coming at you. It's the size of Montana, and it's moving fast. Her TRANSMISSION'S getting STATIC-Y.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: I'm in comm blackout in a few seconds. Find shelter. Now. Any shelter you can -- Just STATIC. She's gone. END INTERCUT. Gallagher and Burchenal are still a little giddy. Pettengill's looking around at the vast nothingness.

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL
dialogues.text: Shelter? Where're we gonna find shelter out here?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Let's go over that ridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher, Burchenal and Pettengill hustle down a hill. They stop, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL
dialogues.text: There's nothing big enough here.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: .+. Winds could hit two-fifty. I was stationed in Antarctica fixing submarines. You didn't want to be caught out in a big blow there, and those were nothing by comparison. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: If you were caught out, what would you do then?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: If you didn't have a choice? Dig a snow-cave. I guess.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: So let's dig one.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: There's no snow. And we can't dig rock. There's a funky-looking hillock nearby. Five feet high, as big around. Burchenal's gone over. He kicks it. The soft volcanic rock crumbles away, revealing... snow.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Permafrost. He scrapes away some.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: And you can dig in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're digging. Burchenal not able to give to it like the other two. Pettengill really working at it. Gallagher puts a hand on him.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Take it easy. Pettengill stops a moment. Breathing hard.

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL
dialogues.text: We've come this far. We gotta make it all the way. We gotta live. As Pettengill rejoins the effort...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've hollowed out the hillock. The WIND'S starting to KICK UP. Gallagher's talking into the radio. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Bowman... Come in, Mars-1... Beat. Nothing. He gives up and crawls inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher crawls in. As he seals the entrance with snow and rocks...

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Reach her?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Still in blackout.

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL
dialogues.text: We can't talk to her from in here?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Signal won't penetrate. He finishes sealing the entrance. They settle in. It's a very tight fit, but not bad considering. Lit by their suit-lights. Burchenal's in obvious pain, cradling his hurt ribs.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Even resting hurts. Beat. Suddenly, they hear a WHISTLE outside. AMEE.

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL
dialogues.text: The wolf's at the door.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: (beat) AMEE's programmed for psy-ops. She's trying to freak us out. She WHISTLES again. Gallagher yells.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Beat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WIND WHIPS ice and dust around AMEE, riding out the storm in her box.  108 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men sit as the DUSTSTORM HOWLS outside. Illuminated by their suit-lights... We see how really trashed these guys are. They look like an Everest expedition caught at camp five for a month. Dirty, bearded, battered, sore, thirsty, hungry, tired, scared, and now shivering with cold. Burchenal has the added burden of his injury. Just checking the time like he does now hurts like a motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: How far's Cosmos from here? Gallagher's lost in thought. Finally realizes Burchenal's asked him something.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Cosmos. How far you think it is?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Five or six hours.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: (checks time) ... Leaves four to try and launch .-. Not counting whatever time we lose here. (beat) Borokovski better have a good memory. Won't be time for plan B. They sit in silence a while. Burchenal thinking hard about something. Then --

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: There's a thing... Something maybe science doesn't fully explain... That drives us on when everything else fails. That extends itself to other people... Like when you kept me going back there. Gallagher meets his eyes. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Chantilas would say it's got something to do with the Almighty. Maybe it does. Or maybe it's just something special about the human spirit... Whatever, I'm grateful for it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RED PLANET - Rev. 11/10/99 75.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 108 Beat. Gallagher doesn't warm to the praise.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I didn't do it because I wanted you to live. I did it because I hated myself for what I was really thinking.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: That if I left you, I'd survive.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: What're you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Cosmos only has room for two people. Beat. Burchenal and Pettengill can't believe it. There's a Burchenal

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL
dialogues.text: You're saying one of us can't go? After all this?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I've already decided. You're both going. (off their looks) The mission's not over if you can get back and tell ‘em what you've seen. That's a helluva lot more important than anything I can offer. (then) I'll help you rig Cosmos. Then we say good-bye. long beat. And a noticeable lack of argument. does have a conscience, though...

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: You're a rare man, Gallagher.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: (beat, then) Hey, we don't know if Cosmos'11l even launch. Even if it does, hell, it's Russian -- it'll probably get ten feet off the ground and blow up, and I'll still live the longest. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 108A
dialogues.text: RED PLANET - Rev. 12/13/99 76.

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL
dialogues.text: Somehow I don't quite believe it.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL
dialogues.text: I've always been the odd one out. Came on as a last minute replacement. Never quite fit in. (re: Burchenal) Now he thinks I'm responsible for Santen's death. Gallagher and Burchenal exchange a look. Pettengill can read into it.

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL
dialogues.text: Don't you trust me, Gallagher? ‘You watch my back, I'11 watch yours?'

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: I know I don't trust you.

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL
dialogues.text: (to Burchenal; sarcastic) But you're gonna leave your buddy behind and take off with me?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: That's right, he is. Pettengill just looks at each of them. Then settles back against the snow, processing it all, capable of anything. OFF Gallagher and Burchenal, exchanging a look as the WIND SHRIEKS outside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowman's pacing to stay awake. Into the portable radio --

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Gallagher... Gallagher, come in... Nothing. But she's going to keep trying.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: C'mon, hear me, Gallagher. I know you're there...  109 110 RED PLANET - Rev. 12/13/99 77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The STORM'S still HOWLING outside. In the suit-lights, we see Pettengill asleep and Burchenal nodding. Gallagher's the only one you'd call awake. But that just barely. Keeping an ear on the storm. An eye on the clock. Still watching over the team, even though he's chosen to die. Too tired to even worry about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowman's still pacing. Checks her watch. Into the radio --

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Gallagher... Hey, you did it before, man. Give me a call. Bus has gotta leave soon... talk to me now... She hears from Houston instead --

dialogues.speaker: CAPCOM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mars-1, this is Houston. Commander, we don't know about your clock, but ours is running out of time down here. You've been outta contact with ‘em three hours. Those boys came a long way on shoestrings, but that's a ferocious storm, and no one could survive it... Here's where it is «+. If you don't punch it in the next window, we're getting down to a gnat's ass. You're risking your life, that ship, and the future of this program -- and your team died for what?... If they haven't made contact by the time you receive this, you're ordered to return home ASAP... We'll catch you coming home... Houston out. There's a long beat. Then Bowman keys the radio. Her words are measured, her tone deliberate.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Houston, Mars-1l... That's a Negative... I'm not leaving ‘til I know... Mars-1 out.  111 RED PLANET - Rev. 12/13/99 77A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher's asleep. He's shivering. So hard it wakes him up. Realizes he's cold because the entrance to the cave is open to the outside. No sound of the storm. Next, he sees Pettengill's missing.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Shit. He turns to Burchenal, asleep on the other side of him.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Burchenal. He shakes him awake.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Pettengill's gone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He quickly looks and feels around the cave.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: He took the radio.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: What's the bastard gonna do, try to take off alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a weird place in the day. At night, lit by Pettengill's suit-light, it's fucking spooky. Pettengill hurrying along. When... .--. he hears a WHISTLE... And now he's scared. Starts to move a lot faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a SHARP BEEP. Gallagher looks down at his arm. On the screen, in infrared AMEE-vision, we see Pettengill. Running madly. The camera chasing him. There's no sound.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Oh, man... Gallagher slows and stops. Burchenal stops beside him.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: (re: the screen) AMEE's got him... She wants us to see it. On screen, we see AMEE'S POV as she closes in on Pettengill and runs him down. There's nothing Gallagher and Burchenal can do about what's going to happen next. They can only watch. Pettengill's cornered. He turns. Faces what he knows is coming. Accepting his fate. Our vision's limited to what AMEE sees. There's no sound. But the brutality of her attack is plain enough. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: AMEE finally slams Pettengill to the ground. She moves in. Gives them a closeup of Pettengill's face... His eyes blink once. Blink again. Nothing else moving. The dull reactions of a spinal cord-injury victim. And then his eyes close. The reaction of a dead man... And then the screen goes dark. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: He thought we were gonna leave him. He made it come true.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: (beat) We need that radio, or no one's going anywhere. As they head off --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Using their suit-lights to see, Gallagher and Burchenal follow Pettengill's tracks. Burchenal checks the time.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: We lost three hours in the snow cave.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: At least Pettengill went in the right direction.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Took a general heading before we went into the snow cave. When we came out, I lined it up with the stars.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: (shivers) It's freezing.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Keep moving. Increasing body activity's the only way to ward off hypothermia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher's suit-light continues to illuminate Pettengill's tracks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 114B
dialogues.text: RED PLANET - Rev. 11/29/99 80.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don't get this. Gallagher turns. Burchenal's stopped. Has his light trained on the ground. We see color.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: There's still algae here. He sweeps the beam out across the landscape. Patches of algae extend out beyond the reach of the light. Glowing pink. Burchenal bends down and grabs a handful. The pinkish glow dissipates as he touches it.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Why's it here and nowhere else?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Too late to figure it out now. We gotta keep moving. Gallagher looks to the horizon. Sees a thin shaft of light shooting straight up.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Pettengill...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They rush across the iridescent landscape until they reach...

dialogues.speaker: PETTENGILL 114B
dialogues.text: Lying on a patch of ground devoid of algae. His face is obscured by the closed helmet, the visor fogged-over. There's a fist-size hole punched through his chest.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: AMEE must've done it.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Let's hope she left the radio. Burchenal takes off his gloves to search Pettengill's suit for the radio. Gallagher tries to open Pettengill's helmet, but it jams, barely open. Whereupon we hear a nerve-fraying, HIGH-PITCHED SOUND from the narrow slot. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 114F
dialogues.text: RED PLANET - Rev. 11/10/99 81.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I hear something inside his helmet.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Why'd he close it? He didn't have any air left. Gallagher finds the radio.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I'll try to raise Bowman. Gallagher moves off. Burchenal puts his ear very close to Pettengill's visor. Looks again at Pettengill's face. ANGLE - PETTENGILL 114¢c His mouth appears to be moving. Burchenal looks closer.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE PETTENGILL'S HELMET 114D
dialogues.text: Several yellowish translucent nematodes wriggle over Pettengill's lips sucking in a human sludge that fills their three-inch bodies.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL 114E
dialogues.text: Mystified, he takes out his ignition lighter. There's a small rotating buzzsaw at the end. Burchenal begins to saw through the visor. Gallagher's had no luck reaching Bowman so far.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: She must be on the back side. Burchenal continues to saw.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE HELMET 114F
dialogues.text: Carbon sparks begin to bounce off the inside of the visor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RED PLANET - Rev. 11/10/99 82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .-. hundreds of fiery nematodes explode. Burchenal staggers back.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Some kind of nematodes. They were eating Pettengill. Sparks ignited 'em. There's a patch of algae near Burchenal. He shines his light on it. We see more nematodes.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: They're feeding on the algae. That's where it went...

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Thought there wasn't any life here.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: There shouldn't be. Burchenal whips out a telescoping rod. A titanium vial on the end.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: They're gonna flip out over this back home. He jabs the rod into the nematodes. A sample is sucked into the vial and frozen by liquid nitrogen. The vial seals shut.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Let's get moving. They begin walking --

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: You sure it's smart to take those things with us?

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Smart?... You don't understand the importance of this, do you?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I'm the janitor, remember? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Earth's losing oxygen. You see how those things burned? They make it. They eat algae, and they make 02... Gallagher, we don't have to move to a new planet if we can save the old one. As Burchenal's words sink in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher and Burchenal walk across a vast field of algae. Gallagher pauses to look.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Been years since I've seen green fields. Burchenal's ahead of Gallagher, when something catches his eye... The algae in front of him has begun to glow. The glow swiftly surges toward him like a wave. The wave reaches his feet, surrounds him. Burchenal shines his light down. In the beam, we see nematodes beginning to swarm up his legs.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Go back!

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: What? Burchenal runs back, the wave moving with him.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Run, goddamn it! Gallagher begins running back the way they came. Burchenal's injured rib slows him. More nematodes catch up. The swarm of nematodes on his legs grows. Burchenal stumbles and falls. Gallagher continues running... When suddenly the glowing wave surges into the algae ahead of him. Gallagher stops. He looks around. The wave of nematodes is moving in on him from all sides. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 117 RED PLANET - Rev. 11/10/99 84.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: We're surrounded. He realizes Burchenal's not there.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Burchenal! Burchenal's on the ground, hurting, his body swarmed by nematodes, some already eating through his suit and beginning to devour him.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Stay there! You won't make it!... Sons of bitches're already inside my suit... Beat. Burchenal struggles out of his life support vest.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: You're outta air. You'll need this for the launch. He tosses the vest to Gallagher. Then --

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: You said you're not important ‘cause you aren't a scientist... You're wrong. Burchenal tosses him the vial containing the nematode sample.

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Accomplish the mission, Gallagher.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Burchenal...

dialogues.speaker: BURCHENAL
dialogues.text: Put your helmet on. It's gonna get hot here in a sec. Burchenal pulls out his ignition lighter. Gallagher draws his helmet over his head. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: So long, Burchenal. Beat. Burchenal manages a smile... Then triggers his lighter and drops it into the sea of nematodes. Instantly, they COMBUST -- an enormous, fiery chain reaction that EXPLODES out across the field and all around Gallagher. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The blaze burns brightly and intensely for a moment, then just as suddenly, is gone. Beat. Gallagher pulls back his helmet and looks around. OFF his reaction --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mars-1 passes through terminus. Day becomes night. An anxious Bowman flips on the Thermal Imager. Searches the Martian suface. Looking for...

dialogues.speaker: THERMAL IMAGING SYSTEM
dialogues.text: «+. a hot spot. ZOOMING IN ON a lone figure moving across the vast, dark coldness of Mars.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Happy and relieved, her faith rewarded by the living presence of at least one member of the team.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Thank God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher pounds it out. Huffing and puffing. Long past the nematodes. AMEE's DRONE HUMMING overhead. Into the radio --

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Gallagher?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Here. INTERCUT Gallagher and Bowman -- Her relief is multiplied knowing Gallagher's made it. Beat. She makes a calculation.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Stop. You're going the wrong way. Gallagher slows.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Which way? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 119 RED PLANET - Rev. 12/15/99 86.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: You have to go back. The way you came. This is too much... Even for Gallapher. He starts to lose it.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I can't... the worms... We found life... Burchenal sacrificed himself for me... They're all dead.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: (reacts, then) Stop... Listen to me. He stops. Swaying with exhaustion and the prospect of defeat. Then drops to his knees.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: If Burchenal gave his life so you'd have a chance, it's your job to take it... You gotta find a way to keep going, or he died for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: «+. I can't... Bowman looks at the warm figure on the screen a moment.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: .-+. Then how about doing it for me?... Get moving, Gallagher. I'll guide you. There's a long beat. Then slowly, Gallagher gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Okay... He gets himself moving.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Okay... Gallagher picks up the pace until he's going as fast as h can.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Okay... OFF Gallagher, gutting it out across cold, dark Martian wasteland.  120 121 122 RED PLANET - Rev. 12/15/99 87.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT 120
dialogues.text: Time has passed. Gallagher runs. Tired but persisting. Navigating by the stars. His suit-light bouncing in the vast emptiness.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Gallagher radios --

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Time.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Fifty-two minutes to go.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I should be there by now.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I could've screwed up the celestial nav. I could be off course.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Stay positive. It's there. Make it be there.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I could've run right past it -- But suddenly, there it is. Right in front of him. Cosmos. In all its rock-probe ugliness. No looming spacecraft, just a small sample container atop a launching base. Hardly confidence-inspiring. And Russian. But...

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I found it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There's no time to experience the relief she feels.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: See? As Gallagher looks over Cosmos, solar panels revolve and track toward his light.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Okay, what do I do now?

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: There's an infrared maintenance port. It should be marked. Gallagher looks for it. Minor stumbling block --

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Yeah. In Cyrillic. Finds it anyhow.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Okay, I got it. Tries to unscrew the cover. Can't.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Hands're too cold. My fingers won't work.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Use your teeth if you have to. Just do it. He flexes his fingers. Tries again. Finally gets the cover off. An IR port inside.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I'm in. What now?

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Connect the radio to Cosmos. I'm gonna download what you need through the modem. Gallagher finds it. Hooks up the radio to Cosmos.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Go. Stuff flashes on the Cosmos' digital readout. The launch program, etc. When it's finished, Gallagher unplugs the modem to speak into the radio again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Still has power.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: You should be able to run diagnostics. He does. System check positive. It's a big moment.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: All green.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: (stops holding her breath) Alright. Now, this thing only has two settings: ‘on' and 'off'... right now, ‘'on' sends it all the way back to Earth. As you lack air, food and water, that'd be bad. She refers to data.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: We want just enough power to reach orbit. I've recalculated for the weight of one person... You gotta take two liters out of each fuel tank. There's a central purge... You'll have to measure it somehow .»+. It's gotta be pretty exact.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Russians couldn't add a gas gauge?

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: (no time for nonsense) I'm going into comm blackout soon, and we're down to forty-nine minutes. Shut up and figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Yessir, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Gallagher's unbolted the rock scoop. Finishes taking crude measurements. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I need you to do some math. A box forty by twenty centimeters and ten high, how deep's four liters? CONTINUE INTERCUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowman quickly does the math.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Call it three centimeters. Gallagher measures and scribes in the line. Moves to the purge valve. Fills the box with four liters of liquid rocket fuel. Sets it down.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Launch diagnostics. Avoid pressing anything that says ‘ignition.' He runs it. Everything's in the green... until it reaches "Ignition Power." Green is 300 volts at six amps. There's exactly zero. It's dead as a doornail. The program suggests the replacement part number. Gallagher stares at the readout, not wanting to believe it. Then slowly lets in the truth: he's not going anywhere after all.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Gallagher?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Ignition battery's dead. There's not enough power to launch.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Is there anything else you can use?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Let me look around and see if I see a high-voltage source... Nope, just rocks. He sits down next to the Cosmos. Beat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I'm gonna die here, Bowman. Bowman's shook.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: I'll figure out how to stay up here longer. We'll find another way.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: You can't stay without burning more fuel to hold orbit. Do that, and you don't make it home... No. You gotta go. It's your duty to get back. Bowman knows he's right... but she hates it. long beat. Words fail her...

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Gallagher...

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: «+. How soon you in blackout?

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: About a minute.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: So we have a minute. And there's some stuff I gotta tell you. First, about the worms... They ate the algae. Maybe Hab, too... But what's important is they make oxygen. I guess that's why we could breathe. Burchenal says they might even be able to save Earth. So get someone back here quick. And tell ‘em to be careful +. These things are omnivores. (beat) That's the big story. Other than that, I just gotta tell you I really hate Mars. I'd never want to live here. I'd miss Earth too much... the way I do now. (then) The way I miss a lot of things. (beat) I should've kissed you, Bowman. 91. 124

dialogues.speaker: A
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: (eyes welling) Yeah. You should've kissed me. (beat) I pretended it didn't matter... And every force inside me was pulling me toward you... Tears are streaming down her cheek now. Gallagher pauses. Half a beat. When...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mars-1 circles into daylight. And...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowman's RADIO suddenly blares STATIC. As...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +.» He goes on to say --

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Good-bye... I'm gonna miss you... But it's too late. There's no response. Only STATIC. A long, long beat. He's alone. He'll be alone for the rest of his life. Sitting on a big, cold rock in space.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: (softly) "Here it comes, here it comes, here it comes -- ' When he's interrupted by a familiar SHARP BEEP. Gallagher looks down. On the screen on his sleeve, we see AMEE's infrared POV as she moves across the Martian landscape.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Letting me know you're still coming, huh? There is a long beat. Gallagher realizes something.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Okay. Come and get me.

dialogues.speaker: BOX
dialogues.text: Part of Cosmos. Gallagher removing some fasteners and opening it. Revealing a bundle of white fabric inside. Cosmos' re-entry parachute. He picks up the bucket of rocket fuel. OFF Gallagher, pouring it into the box and soaking the chute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING INTO a position twenty yards from Gallagher, who's against Cosmos again.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER 129
dialogues.text: looks at AMEE.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Ready to move in for the kill, huh? Okay. Come on over and finish me. Then you can be up here all alone. Just walking around Mars whistling to yourself. She keeps coming.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: .-. Couldn't happen to a nicer girl... AMEE walks right up to him. Not a pause. Raises an arm into the air. Gonna plunge it into Gallagher's brain. When... ++. at the last possible second, Gallagher jerks away from the death-blow. Rolls over. Underneath Cosmos. Triggers a switch he's wired there, and... BOOM! Cosmos' PARACHUTE SHOOTS out of its box, which is positioned so as to kick the chute out laterally. The chute engulfing AMEE. Gallagher now rolling out from under Cosmos. Pulling out his torch, and... ... the fuel-soaked parachute EXPLODES into FLAMES. The fire all around her. Burning up into her maintenance port, which Gallagher'd opened to Hab and never closed again. Melting circuitry and wiring there. Even as the parachute burns away, the fire in AMEE's bell is starting to disrupt her behavior... Her movements become erratic. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gallagher'd like to wait, but he doesn't have time. Moves in on her. A metal rod from Cosmos in his hand. AMEE tries to fight him off. Lands blows. But there's no coordination. No ability to follow up. And finally... Gallagher grabs an arm. Flips her over. Stabs the rod deep into the open, smoldering port on her underside. Into her exposed CPU. Once. Twice... and then it's over. She stops moving. Lies still. Gallagher looks down at her.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: I'm getting off this planet. Gallagher removes another port cover. Starts to reach inside. When suddenly... AMEE grabs his wrist in her pincers. Gallagher plunges the rod into her one more time, and the pincers release, the hand falls. Gallagher reaches into the second port again, dredging up AMEE's E-source -- a power cell the size of a soda can. Disconnects it. If this were the jungle, AMEE would be a slain animal, the battery would be her heart -- and Gallagher would celebrate his victory by eating it. Here, now, he's gotta get into space...

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Gallagher finishes jerry-rigging the battery inside AMEE. Shuts the battery port and begins sweeping rocks out of the sample container -- his "capsule." Gallagher's about to pull his helmet over his head... when he stops... He rips something. Skewers it on the rod that finished off AMEE. Bends OUT OF FRAME and does something we can't see. Gallagher turns back to Cosmos. And now we see... «+. the American flag patch from the shoulder of his suit. "Flying" from the rod. Planted in the Martian turf. Gallagher pulls his helmet on. Looks at the tiny rocket with its rock box.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: This should be interesting....  131 132 133 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher slides into the sample container. There's supposed to be room for two. There's barely room for one. But he's in. Beat. Gallagher takes several deep breaths. Closes his eyes. And punches it. We hear the IGNITION kick ON... and then, with a GRINDING ROAR, the thirty-year-old ROCKET MOTORS COME TO LIFE. Inside his capsule, Gallagher's rocked by vibration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wide canyon where Cosmos lies lights up from the enormous EXPLOSION of the ENGINE. And, slowly at first, the little ship begins to rise. Gallagher's rattled harder by vibration. And now, as Cosmos picks up speed, the g-forces press him against the hard floor of the box. The heat shield glows bright red two inches from Gallagher's face. When the second stage kicks in, the force rips the shield away completely. MICRO DUST PINGS against Gallagher's visor. Inside the helmet, his eyes and ears begin to bleed. His face distorts from the 9-g's pulling down on him. Cosmos reaches the atmospheric envelope. And bursts through. Released from Mars' gravity and atmospheric friction, Cosmos accelerates. Gallagher's head is snapped sideways by the increased velocity. And then, at last, the second-stage ROCKET MOTORS SPUTTER and DIE. The second stage falls away... Cosmos floats in the deathly quiet of space...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowman's making final preparations for her return. When her eyes go to a screen on the instrument panel... Something's shot up into the atmosphere ahead of her... She looks up from the screen, looks out the window. Beat. It hits her... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Gallagher... Then, to the voice-activated computer system --

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Abort. Reroute. Orbital maneuvering. Power the O.M.S. Power the R.C.S. She flips a joystick out from underneath the dash in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: I need roll, pitch, yaw, X, Y, Z. She's flying the ship now.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Ten millimeter bursts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small HYDROGEN BURSTS begin to shift Mars-1. Bit by bit the large ship dives down into a lower orbit to catch Cosmos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher drifts on the edge of unconsciousness. On his wrist display, we see that Burchenal's life-support pack is running low on air. Mars-1 approaches. Closer and closer. More HYDROGEN BLASTS slow Mars-1. Both ships nearing the daylight. And when Mars-1 is as close as Bowman dares bring it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She triggers a final breaking burst. Throws off her seat harness.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT 137
dialogues.text: Bowman races through the ship. Exits into...

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bowman runs herself across the room. Jams her feet into EVA boots. Moves upward into the EVA upper body section. Locks it shut. Fully encased now. Like a large crustacean with legs.  139 140 141 142 143 RED PLANET - Rev. 11/29/99 97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallagher's out of air. He's either unconscious... or dead. Cosmos and Mars-1 entering the sunlight now.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Seal this level! Open the dock! The large outer doors of the dock open. Air and loose items purge. Gallagher and Cosmos float 300 yards away. Bowman unclips her suit from its anchoring device and yanks something off the wall. Like a 40mm grenade launcher with a power retrieval cable. Bowman shoulders it. Aims. Pulls the trigger... the device emits a thin laser beam.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN 142
dialogues.text: regards a readout on the gun: "OBJECT OUT OF RANGE." She lets go of the gun. Looks around. Propels herself up to the long "Canadian arm" which is used to bring Hab into the bay. The arm attached to a linear acceleration track pointing out the open hatch. A receptacle on the back of Bowman's EVA suit matches the large Hab retrieval ball on the end of the arm. Bowman backs herself against the ball. Clips her suit onto it.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Last acquisition. Line release. Full velocity. And the linear accelerator shoots the arm down the track and hurls Bowman out into space. The ball stays embedded in her back. Trailing a line back to Mars-1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bowman flies toward Gallagher and Cosmos. No means of stopping herself. Crashes hard into Cosmos. Momentarily stuns herself. Then recovers. Moves to Gallagher. Puts her visor against his. And screams.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Gallagher! Gallagher! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She's shouting at the top of her lungs, but inside Gallagher's helmet there's only a muffled HUM transmitted through two face-plates. Bowman grabs onto Cosmos. Says something we can't hear. The linear accelerator yanks her violently backward. Begins retracting Bowman and Cosmos back toward the open Hab retrieval bay. Mars-1 is swallowing up Bowman, Cosmos and Gallagher. At 45 mph. They almost make it through the door cleanly. Cosmos catches slightly on one side. Flips them around as they plunge inside.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Cosmos rams the end of the arm. The arm fractures away but still stops Cosmos from ramming through the inner bulkhead and destroying Mars-1.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Seal! Emergency atmosphere! Now! The OUTER DOOR SLAMS SHUT. The room is buffeted in a white mist. The atmosphere is restored. Gallagher's limp, unresponsive. Bowman checks his readout. No air. No heartbeat.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Not after all this, damn it. She grabs an emergency cutting tool. Hooks it into the front of Gallagher's suit. Rips it open from stem to stern. A first-aid station is bolted to the wall. Bowman grabs a pair of paddles from a defibrillation unit. Jabs them against Gallagher's chest. As she triggers them --

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE GALLAGHER'S BODY 145
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW the ELECTRICAL SHOCK as it courses through neural networks and reaches his heart. ZAP! Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN 146
dialogues.text: sees there's no response. Dials up the defibrillator. Hits him with the paddles again. Once more --  147 148 149 150 151 RED PLANET - Rev. 11/29/99 99.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE GALLAGHER'S BODY
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW the millisecond path of the CHARGE. It reaches his heart. ZAP!

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: regards the readout on the defibrillator. It's bouncing with Gallagher's restored pulse. Gallagher slowly begins to regain consciousness...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mars-1 hurtles by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter. Look around. Lotsa missing faces. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Let's hope it was worth the cost.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Houston thinks so... On Earth, they're calling you a hero. (beat) I haven't told them about Pettengill. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: (beat) We were put into a situation we didn't expect and weren't ready for. We all made mistakes. Things we'd take back if we could... Four men died. But in the end, we accomplished the mission. (beat) That's what people should remember. That the men who died down there were all heroes, too. Beat. Gallagher reaches into his pocket. Pulls out a rock and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Memento?

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Something for Chantilas's family. (beat) His faith got us through. Bowman gazes up at him. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: I'll say it again: you're not who I thought you were. Gallagher meets her gaze... then draws her to him and kisses her. It's been a long time coming. They both make it last. And then, holding her, smiling, looking into her eyes --

dialogues.speaker: GALLAGHER
dialogues.text: Universe is full of surprises. And that's the way we leave them. Holding each other. Tired. At the beginning of a long journey. The CAMERA PUSHING IN ON the small rock in Gallagher's hand until it FILLS the FRAME and SLOWLY TRANSFORMS INTO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Red Planet. Cold and forbidding. Floating in the jet black of space. FADE OUT.
